author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Reopening Schools: Senator Patty Murray Says Congress Needs to Step Up
description: She isn’t optimistic that Congress will help schools reopen safely in the fall: “There’s going to be a lot of parents in tears.”
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Bent Fabric, Pianist and Composer Known for ‘Alley Cat,’ Dies at 95
description: A simple tune with an old-time feel, it could embed itself in the listener’s ear as if on a continuous loop. In 1962, it became a worldwide hit.
content: Bent Fabricius-Bjerre, the Danish pianist who, as Bent Fabric, composed and recorded the ubiquitous instrumental hit “Alley Cat,” died on Tuesday. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: The New College Drop-Off
description: A bittersweet family tradition has become an exercise in risk assessment, logistics and trying to understand ever-changing rules.
content: Maureen Rayhill of Seattle sounds like a public health official as she describes the current process for coronavirus testing, rattling off research she’s done on in-person testing centers versus mail-order companies and how their turnaround times for results compare. But she’s not. She’s a mother, just trying to get her oldest child to college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Federal Agencies Agree to Withdraw From Portland, With Conditions
description: Gov. Kate Brown of Oregon said the teams would begin a withdrawal on Thursday. Federal officials cautioned that they would withdraw only when they were confident the federal courthouse could be secured.
content: For days, as fireworks and tear gas erupted in the streets of Portland, Ore., during the deployment of federal tactical teams cracking down on raucous demonstrations, President Trump campaigned against protesters he described as “sick and deranged anarchists & agitators” who he said had threatened to leave Portland “burned and beaten to the ground.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: We Have Questions
description: How to get answers from the tech executives testifying at a high-profile congressional hearing today.
content: Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Ackermann
title: I Cured My Pandemic Anxiety by Making Tiny Food Out of Clay
description: The subtle pleasures of trying to make one small piece of the world just right.
content: I’ve always hated cooking. My mother thought it was drudgery; her mother felt the same. As for me, a tech worker, I hid in my profession’s disdain for inefficiency. The calculus of exchanging time or money for feeding my family never balanced in cooking’s favor. For a perfectionist like me (another matrilineal inheritance) long recipes looked like baroque forms of self-torture; there wasn’t even time to shop at the good grocery store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: In the Hudson Valley: Live Dancers, Real Sweat, Natural Beauty
description: Almost all dance in the United States has gone virtual. But Kaatsbaan will fill the void, hosting its first-ever festival.
content: TIVOLI, N.Y. — This summer, as stages around the country lie empty and unused, Kaatsbaan, in Tivoli, N.Y., will be something precious and rare: one of the few places in America where dancers will be performing live, in person, in front of a living and breathing, if well-distanced and masked audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Congress Doesn’t Get Big Tech. By Design.
description: Members of Congress may say dumb things at the tech hearing, but it’s not necessarily their fault.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Latest on Biden’s V.P. Timeline
description: The presumptive nominee rolls out a racial justice plan: This is your politics tip sheet.
content: With Trump pushing schools to reopen, teachers’ unions say: safety first. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: A Viral Epidemic Splintering Into Deadly Pieces
description: There’s not just one coronavirus outbreak in the United States. Now there are many, each requiring its own mix of solutions.
content: Once again, the coronavirus is ascendant. As infections mount across the country, it is dawning on Americans that the epidemic is now unstoppable, and that no corner of the nation will be left untouched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pooja Lakshmin
title: How to Handle Anxiety Over Back-to-School Decisions
description: While parents may be feeling unsure about school options this fall, there are ways to feel better as you make the tough decision.
content: A combination of dread, panic and sheer exhaustion. This is what I see on the faces of patients (and friends and colleagues) when the conversation turns to the most pressing topic on every parent’s mind: what to do about school in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Litsky
title: Lou Henson, Final Four Coach With Two Schools, Dies at 88
description: A genial “old school” leader, he took New Mexico State and then Illinois deep into the N.C.A.A. tournament. In a 42-year career, he won close to 800 games.
content: Lou Henson, who led New Mexico State and the University of Illinois to the Final Four in a 42-year head-coaching career in which he piled up almost 800 victories, died on Saturday at his home in Champaign, Ill. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: U.S. Surpasses 150,000 Coronavirus Deaths, Far Eclipsing Projections
description: The national toll shows how difficult predicting the virus — or human behavior — can be. President Trump and leading experts have at times said that deaths would be much lower.
content: The United States’ leading authority on infectious disease expressed hope in April that no more than 60,000 people in the country would die from the coronavirus. A revered research center predicted a few weeks later that the figure would be just over 70,000 people by early August. When the number of deaths shot up in May, President Trump said that anywhere between 75,000 and 100,000 people could die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces New Grants
description: This round of funding, the final for the fiscal year, totals $30 million and will support 238 projects.
content: The Amistad Research Center’s holdings on African-American history, a new biography of the poet Robert Frost and a traveling exhibition commemorating the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are among the 238 recipients of new grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russian propaganda, U.K. quarantine, van Gogh: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Newly declassified U.S. intelligence accuses Russia of spreading misinformation about the coronavirus pandemic, as it tries to influence Americans with the November election approaching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Kapczynski, Paul Biddinger and Rochelle Walensky
title: Remdesivir Could Be in Short Supply. Here’s a Fix.
description: The federal government must work to ensure adequate supply of the coronavirus drug — and distribute it evenly and transparently.
content: Remdesivir is no Covid-19 miracle cure. We do not even know yet if it saves lives, but clinical trials do show that it can shorten hospital stays, and right now it’s the only drug known to interfere with coronavirus activity in the body. Doctors everywhere rightly want to give it to severely ill patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
title: As Trump Undercuts Aid Talks, White House Says Extra Jobless Benefits Will Lapse
description: President Trump signaled that he was not interested in a broad economic recovery package that would have to be negotiated with Democrats, saying he preferred a narrower plan.
content: WASHINGTON — The prospects for a quick agreement between the Trump administration and congressional Democrats on a new round of aid for the ailing economy faded on Wednesday, as President Trump undercut his own party’s efforts to negotiate a deal and a top White House official declared that a lifeline to unemployed workers would run out as scheduled at week’s end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Gregor
title: House Hunting in Nova Scotia: A Sprawling Seaside Villa for $2 Million
description: The eastern Canadian province has managed to make up for the loss of foreign buyers with more domestic transactions, staving off the worst of the pandemic.
content: This five-bedroom seaside mansion with Atlantic Ocean views is perched on a headland jutting into Mahone Bay in the village of Chester, on the South Shore of Nova Scotia, Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iman Stevenson
title: The Black Book Club Takes It to the Next Level
description: Noname and other Black thought leaders have taken what Oprah built and made something new.
content: “I want people to think radically,” said Noname, the 28-year-old rapper, in a phone interview this month from her home in Los Angeles. She is outspoken, especially on Twitter, about dismantling patriarchy, white supremacy and capitalism, but over the last year she has also been opening people’s minds through a more analog medium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: How to Fight Against Big Tech’s Power
description: We are beholden to a few Big Tech overlords for much of our digital lives. We can be more conscientious about it.
content: In the morning, you check email. At noon, you browse social media and message friends. In the evening, you listen to music while shopping online. Around bedtime, you curl up with an e-book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Benches Clear in First Astros-Dodgers Game Since Cheating Revelations
description: The Dodgers lost to the Astros in the 2017 World Series and were not pleased to learn about Houston’s cheating scheme that year. When they faced off Tuesday, things got testy.
content: Yeah, the other teams still don’t like the Astros very much.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Overwhelmed Funeral Homes in South Texas Struggle to Keep Up
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 29, 2020.
content: “I tell them, stop sending them. We are tired. We haven’t stopped. We need to sleep.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim
title: Why Revel Suspended Moped Service in N.Y.C.
description: The app's electric-blue rental vehicles have become popular, but crashes, resulting in two  deaths this month, have added to safety concerns.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Matt Furber
title: Where George Floyd Was Killed: Solemn by Day, Violent by Night
description: Two months after the killing of Mr. Floyd, a South Minneapolis neighborhood remains a police-free zone.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Still, they come — from all over the country and beyond. From New Mexico, Texas, Massachusetts. From Africa and Europe. One man even said he walked a thousand miles, all the way from Alabama, just to be in Minneapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Gordon Lightfoot: If You Could Read My Mind’ Review: A Troubadour Looks Back
description: The singer-songwriter, now 81, is frank about his own work and refreshingly open to today’s music.
content: If you haven’t laid eyes on the singer-songwriter Gordon Lightfoot in a while, you may be stunned at the beginning of this straightforward, engaging documentary about his life and work, directed by Martha Kehoe and Joan Tosoni. Now 81 years old, Lightfoot doesn’t resemble the curly-haired, oft-mustachioed, outdoorsy-looking troubadour of his 1970s heyday. Skinny, his clean-shaven face now long and almost gaunt, his hair straight and combed back, he looks like an aged underground rocker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: It’s Summertime, and the Gardening Should Be Easy, Right?
description: Actually, there’s a lot you still need to do. Here’s a list to get you started.
content: For any gardener, high summer is quiet compared to spring or fall, with the requisite cleanup. But while it may not be a time for ambitious planting projects, it is a time for ongoing maintenance — especially chores that pay off long-term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Katherine Hoffman, ‘Eternal’ Florida State Figure, Dies at 105
description: From the 1930s to the 2010s, as a student, professor and distinguished alumna, she was a model citizen in support of the school. She died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: ‘Hidden Gem’ Made Popular by TikTok Is Shut to Keep Out-of-Towners Away
description: A lake in New Jersey was closed to curb the spread of the coronavirus, but some complaints about recent crowding there focused on the ethnicity of visitors.
content: HIGH BRIDGE, N.J. — Lake Solitude it was not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Gum Disease Tied to Alzheimer’s Disease Risk
description: Severe gingivitis with tooth loss was associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.
content: Severe gum disease and tooth loss may be linked to an increased risk for developing dementia, a new study has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: He Videotaped the Rodney King Beating. Now, He Is Auctioning the Camera.
description: “How much does something like this go for?” asked George Holliday. “I have no idea.” Bidding begins at $225,000.
content: When Rodney King was on the ground, getting kicked, hit with batons and shot with Tasers by several members of the Los Angeles Police Department in 1991, the episode was captured on video by a man who lived across the street from the attack and happened to have a new camcorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey and Pam Belluck
title: School Closures in the Spring Saved Lives, Study Asserts
description: But, experts caution, the findings highlight a period when few precautions were in place, and do not apply to current discussions about reopening schools.
content: In a new analysis, pediatric researchers have estimated that the states’ decisions to close schools last spring likely saved tens of thousands of lives from Covid-19 and prevented many more coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian M. Rosenthal and Patricia Mazzei
title: Val Demings Is on Biden’s V.P. List. Will Her Police Career Hurt or Help?
description: The former police chief in Orlando, Fla., Ms. Demings has emerged as a finalist to be Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s running mate. A review of her record shows a complicated history with episodes involving police misconduct.
content: An Orlando police officer shoved a 27-year-old Hispanic woman down a flight of stairs, breaking her ankle. A jury ordered him to pay her medical bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: For Senegal’s Biggest Holiday, a Shortage of the All-Important Sheep
description: Properly celebrating Tabaski, as Eid al-Adha is known in Senegal, requires a sacrificial sheep. Coronavirus restrictions have made the animals more expensive, putting them out of reach of many.
content: MISSIRAH, Senegal — The couscous was all ready for the lunchtime crowd in Yassin Dicko’s restaurant near one of the biggest sheep markets in Senegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Schiffer
title: Secondhand Shoppers Worry About Their Favorite Local Spots
description: Sites like Poshmark and Thredup have thrived during the pandemic, but your neighborhood thrift store is not doing so well.
content: For the last four months, Laurie Sigelman, an accountant in her late 40s who lives in the Studio City neighborhood of Los Angeles, has been waiting impatiently for her favorite stores on Melrose Avenue to reopen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni, Maggie Haberman and Sydney Ember
title: Trump Plays on Racist Fears of Terrorized Suburbs to Court White Voters
description: President Trump painted a false picture of suburbs under siege, saying he was protecting them from low-income housing, as he seeks to win over white voters who were key to his 2016 victory.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump vowed on Wednesday to protect suburbanites from low-income housing being built in their neighborhoods, making an appeal to white suburban voters by trying to stir up racist fears about affordable housing and the people who live there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: It’s Time to Head to the Woods
description: Answering a reader’s question about what to do with vacation time when standard travel seems problematic.
content: Welcome. Life at home seems about where it was a week ago, in this age where it seems to be Wednesday every day, though where I stay we are heading into the dog pound of summer, fans whirring everywhere against the heat. It’s hard to stay focused, hard to seek pleasure against the pressures of the work day or the day spent looking for work, when so many of us are still at home as summer beats on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: How Do You Know a Human Wrote This?
description: Machines are gaining the ability to write, and they are getting terrifyingly good at it.
content: I’ve never really worried that computers might be gunning for my job. To tell the truth, often, I pray for it. How much better would my life be — how much better would my editor’s life be, to say nothing of the poor readers — if I could ask an all-knowing machine to suggest the best way to start this column? It would surely beat my usual writing process, which involves clawing at my brain with a rusty pickax in the dim hope that a few flakes of wisdom and insight might, like dandruff, settle on the page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: U.S. Will Cut 12,000 Forces in Germany
description: Defense Department officials say the redeployments will enhance American security and its ability to respond to threats. Allies and some in Congress see it as punishment for Germany.
content: The United States is cutting back its deployments in Germany by nearly 12,000 troops and shifting some of those forces around the continent, including relocating some units to Belgium and Italy, Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: The Go-Go’s Made History 38 Years Ago. There’s Still More to Their Story.
description: A new documentary about the Los Angeles band explores the punk roots that came before its pop sheen, and the power dynamics that led to its split.
content: In March 1982, “Beauty and the Beat” — that classic, effervescent, catch-a-wave-of-pink-champagne debut by the Los Angeles band the Go-Go’s — made history: It became the first record by an all-female group who wrote its own songs and played its own instruments to hit No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. Thirty-eight years later, it’s hard to decide what’s more of a shock: That it took so long to happen, or that it hasn’t happened since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Some teachers’ unions are threatening to strike if districts don’t take sufficient precautions.
content: The school year is on the verge of starting in much of the United States, and the country is still deep in a debate over whether, how and when to bring students back. The White House is pushing for a full return to classrooms, school officials are struggling with safety precautions, and concerned parents are becoming increasingly desperate as their children have fallen behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry Hannon
title: Jockeys Know the ‘Pick Yourself Up’ Mantra Well
description: Diane Crump, who in 1970 became the first woman to ride in the Kentucky Derby, has proved resilient in her career.
content: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV Today: ‘The Weight of Gold’ and ‘The Hater’
description: A documentary exploring the effects of the Olympics on athletes’ mental health airs on HBO. And a Polish thriller comes to Netflix.
content: THE WEIGHT OF GOLD (2020) 9 p.m. on HBO. “I thought of myself as just a swimmer, and not a human being,” Michael Phelps, the most decorated Olympian of all time, says in the trailer for “The Weight of Gold.” Phelps shares his struggles with mental health in this documentary, for which he is also an executive producer. He is joined by several well-known Olympians including Shaun White, Apolo Ohno, Lolo Jones, Sasha Cohen and Bode Miller, who discuss the mental health challenges they have faced after the Olympic Games. The documentary is airing during what was supposed to be the 2020 Tokyo Games, before the event was postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Michael Gold
title: Video of N.Y.P.D. Pulling Protester Into Unmarked Van Draws Criticism
description: The video of the woman’s arrest, shared widely on social media, was met with calls for an explanation from the police.
content: New York City police officers, several in plain clothes, swooped into a demonstration against aggressive police tactics on Tuesday and arrested a protester they appeared to have singled out, pulling her into an unmarked minivan before driving off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: U.S. Open Will Play in Westchester Without Fans
description: The rest of the PGA Tour events and all men’s golf major championships except the Masters have announced plans to play without spectators.
content: The outlook for fans attending a major men’s golf championship this year grew bleaker on Wednesday when officials for the 2020 United States Open announced the event in Westchester County, N.Y., would be conducted without spectators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: The World’s Greatest Directors Have Their Own Streaming Lists
description: A French platform asked auteurs to put together their ideal cinémathèques. It turns out filmmakers with seemingly little in common share favorite movies.
content: To heck with algorithms: Sometimes, you need a human touch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Memers Have a New Campaign Aimed at Getting Trump Out of Office
description: Meme 2020, the social media collective that supported Michael Bloomberg’s presidential primary run, is back with a new focus: mail-in ballot registration.
content: Meme 2020, the collective of social media influencers and content creators that posted sponsored content in support of Michael Bloomberg’s Democratic presidential primary run, is back with a new campaign aimed at preventing the re-election of President Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump Is Trying to Bend Reality to His Will
description: Can his aggressive version of ethnonationalist populism prevail in 2020? The answer is not obvious.
content: Disruption, disorder and disease are gripping the United States as the 2020 election draws near, leading to an unusual degree of unpredictability about our political future. Despite current state and national polling that favors Democrats, we still can’t say for sure whether the nation will tip left or right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Wilkinson
title: A Food Writer’s Sicilian Pasta Dish — and Tips for Sharing It
description: Skye McAlpine has made a name for herself serving bountiful meals to large groups of friends. During lockdown, she’s discovered the joy of cooking for just one or two.
content: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Divided and Demoralized on Virus Aid, Republicans Ask, ‘What’s in the Bill?’
description: Senators in the party are “all over the lot” on the pandemic bill as jobless benefits run out and the fate of any legislative deal remains uncertain.
content: WASHINGTON — When it comes to the new coronavirus recovery package roiling the capital, Senator John Kennedy of Louisiana could use some detective help from the F.B.I., which has unexpectedly found itself an unwitting accomplice in a legislative meltdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart Stevens
title: We Lost the Battle for the Republican Party’s Soul Long Ago
description: Only fear will motivate the party to change — the cold fear only defeat can bring.
content: After Mitt Romney lost the 2012 presidential race, the Republican National Committee chairman, Reince Priebus, commissioned an internal party study to examine why the party had won the popular vote only once since 1988.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Even With an Early Outbreak, Baseball Still Has a Path Forward
description: The sport is grappling with the wisdom of continuing the season after the coronavirus infiltrated the Marlins’ roster. But many players remain committed to playing.
content: Jeff Katz stopped by the Hall of Fame on Tuesday in Cooperstown, N.Y., where he served three terms as mayor. It was strange, he thought, to see no plaques in the gallery for the 2020 class, headlined by Derek Jeter. The plaques were always in place on the Tuesday after induction ceremonies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezekiel J. Emanuel, Saskia Popescu and James Phillips
title: Opening Schools Won’t Be Easy, but Here’s How to Do It Safely
description: Not all schools will be able to restart. For those that can, the focus should be on more than just the classroom.
content: As we wrestle in the next few weeks over which of the nation’s schools to reopen — and let’s be clear, not all of them will be safe to restart — we need to understand this: Kindergarten through the 12th grade involves more than just the classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein, Veronica Penney and Lisa Friedman
title: It’s Summer. Let’s Talk About Hockey.
description: Also this week, health benefits from cutting emissions
content: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Panel Takes Aim at Heavy-Handed Police Tactics at Protests
description: The comments by the United Nations Human Rights Committee come as the Trump administration faces growing criticism for deploying federal agents to confront Black Lives Matter protesters.
content: GENEVA — Law-enforcement authorities are obligated to protect and facilitate peaceful demonstrations, an influential United Nations human rights panel said on Wednesday, challenging tactics the police have used against anti-racism protests in American cities and around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Freight Train Catches Fire and Derails in Arizona
description: The derailment, on a bridge over a lake in Tempe, caused part of the bridge to collapse, the authorities said. No injuries were reported.
content: A freight train derailed and caught fire as it was crossing a heavy rail bridge in Tempe, Ariz., on Wednesday morning, causing the bridge to partially collapse and sending plumes of black smoke billowing over the Tempe Town Lake, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: ‘Scary Misinformation Trump’ Is Back, Says Jimmy Fallon
description: “It’s like Crazy Trump was away for a week and then someone said ‘hydroxychloroquine’ three times,” Fallon said after the president shared another dubious video.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: Whence Came Stonehenge’s Stones? Now We Know
description: Last year archaeologists pinpointed the origin of many of the ancient monument’s massive stones. A new study identifies the source of the rest.
content: Back in the 30s — the 1130s — the Welsh cleric Geoffrey of Monmouth created the impression that Stonehenge was built as a memorial to a bunch of British nobles slain by the Saxons. In his “Historia Regum Britanniae,” Geoffrey tells us that Merlin, the wizard of Arthurian legend, was enlisted to move a ring of giant mystical stones from Mount Killaraus in Ireland to what is commonly believed to be Salisbury Plain, a chalk plateau in southern England, where Stonehenge is located.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Senate Report: Opaque Art Market Helped Oligarchs Evade Sanctions
description: Congressional investigators said companies tied to two Russians under sanctions were able to buy art using shell companies and an intermediary.
content: Companies linked to two Russian oligarchs exploited the opaqueness of the art world to buy high-value art, bypassing U.S. sanctions, according to a report by the U.S. Senate’s Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations that was published on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Eliza Shapiro
title: Teachers Are Wary of Returning to Class, and Online Instruction Too
description: Unions are threatening to strike if classrooms reopen, but are also pushing to limit live remote teaching. Their demands will shape pandemic education.
content: As the nation heads toward a chaotic back-to-school season, with officials struggling over when to reopen classrooms and how to engage children online, teachers’ unions are playing a powerful role in determining the shape of public education as the coronavirus pandemic continues to rage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: M.L.B.’s Botched Return Could Be a Warning for the N.F.L.
description: Baseball’s coronavirus outbreak is a cautionary tale for a league returning without sequestering players. It may be too late for the N.F.L. to change plans.
content: N.F.L., you’re on the clock. Now that nearly every major North American sports league has resumed some form of play, it’s the N.F.L.’s turn to see if it can navigate the coronavirus pandemic as red flags arise at every turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen, Ben Casselman and Gillian Friedman
title: An Extra $600 a Week Kept Many Jobless Workers Afloat. Now What Will They Do?
description: A supplement to unemployment benefits is at an end, and Congress is deadlocked over new aid. For some, that means hunger, evictions or bankruptcies.
content: For Sara Gard, the government’s safety net moved smoothly into place when the coronavirus pandemic upended her family’s lives. Jobless benefit checks began arriving a few days after she was furloughed in April from an entertainment company in Atlanta. A $600 weekly supplement, part of an emergency federal program, would cover the mortgage until her company resumed operations — probably in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kreda
title: Divergent Paths Bring Rangers and Islanders to Same Postseason Start
description: The two teams were going in opposite directions when the N.H.L.’s regular season was halted in mid-March. Both will try to speed into playoff mode, starting with an exhibition game on Wednesday.
content: After a four-month pandemic pause to the N.H.L. season, the Rangers and the Islanders find themselves at the same point — with a berth in a play-in round in the league’s expanded playoffs, which begin this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Steinhauer
title: Five Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
description: Our critic shares accounts that make her feel, think and see in new ways — something that feels especially vital right now.
content: Coronavirus cases in New York are at a reassuring low, and the state is on its way to reopening. That includes art galleries, which are starting to welcome people back, mostly by appointment. I recently visited two, but am mostly remaining cautious and spending the bulk of my time at home. At this point, everything in my apartment looks incredibly uninteresting (except for my cats), so I’m grateful that Instagram continues to provide a small portal of escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Make a no-recipe recipe for gochujang spaghetti, or follow some more formal instruction and prepare a sheet-pan baked feta.
content: Good morning. I’ve been cooking two or three squares a day for 133 days now, surely the longest run of my cooking life, and if it’s sometimes a chore, I still thrill to the possibilities of an improvisatory session — a no-recipe recipe made with what’s on hand. I love those “recipes,” which are really just outlines, notes that others can make into dishes that become entirely their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: As the Pandemic Forced Layoffs, C.E.O.s Gave Up Little
description: Some corporate bosses offered to cut their pay, but most did not. Those who did gave up less than 10 percent of what they received last year.
content: When the pandemic prompted companies to furlough or lay off thousands of employees, some chief executives decided to show solidarity by forgoing some of their pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: City Praises Contact-Tracing Program. Workers Call Rollout a ‘Disaster.’
description: The contact tracers said the program was confusing and disorganized in its first six weeks, leaving them fearful that their work would not have an impact on the virus.
content: It was only a few weeks into the rollout of New York City’s much-heralded contact-tracing program, a vital initiative in the effort to contain the coronavirus and to reopen the local economy. But in private messaging channels, the newly hired contact tracers were already expressing growing misgivings about their work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Information Contagion
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Sinclair Broadcast Group recently published an online interview with a conspiracy theorist who claimed that Dr. Anthony Fauci created the coronavirus using monkey cells. Sinclair — which operates almost 200 television stations — has also run segments downplaying the severity of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Paris Beehives Trace Notre-Dame’s Toxic Fallout
description: Bees can act as tiny pollution detectors, say researchers, who found higher but still safe lead levels in honey gathered downwind of the cathedral.
content: The hundreds of tons of lead that burned in the April 2019 fire that nearly destroyed Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris created a dangerous dust that landed in parks, buildings and playgrounds, raising health alarms. Now, scientists say, some of that lead has found its way to a surprising place: honey produced by urban beehives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Turkey Passes Law Extending Sweeping Powers Over Social Media
description: The legislation extends control over platforms like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube. Critics worry it will be used to stifle dissent and criticism of the government.
content: Turkish lawmakers passed legislation on Wednesday that would give the government sweeping new powers to regulate social media content, raising concerns that one of the few remaining spaces for free public debate in the country could fall under greater government control.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Optics and the Politics of the Protests
description: “I worry that protesters destroying property or retaliating against federal forces, however justified, are playing right into Mr. Trump’s hands,” writes a reader.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Barr Repeats Trump Falsehoods in Congressional Testimony
description: The attorney general echoed many of the president’s inaccurate claims on nationwide protests, police shootings and the coronavirus.
content: Attorney General William P. Barr, in a contentious congressional hearing on Tuesday, defended President Trump and the Justice Department on a variety of matters. Here is a fact-check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Kathleen Gray
title: Michigan Threatens to Slip From Trump as He Goes Quiet on Airwaves
description: The president has started spending more money on ads in much smaller Electoral College prizes like Iowa and Nevada, and in recent days his campaign stopped buying ads in Michigan entirely.
content: President Trump’s campaign has quietly receded from the television airwaves in Michigan in recent weeks, shifting money elsewhere as one of the key Midwestern states that powered his surprise victory in 2016 threatens to move more firmly back into the Democratic column in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert F. Worth
title: Inside the Iraqi Kleptocracy
description: Corruption, as much as violence, makes Iraq unlivable. It helped fuel the rise of ISIS. And America provides the cash to sustain it, at least $10 billion a year in hard currency.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Why You’ll See Two Figures for G.D.P. Decline: Very Big, and Huge
description: Official data for second-quarter economic output arrives Thursday, and while it will be unquestionably bad, there are different ways of looking at it.
content: When the Commerce Department releases its preliminary estimate for second-quarter economic output on Thursday morning, the numbers will be historically terrible.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 29, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 29, 2020.
content: An article on Tuesday about Confederate identity in Lexington, Va., misspelled the given name of a member of the Lexington City Council. She is Marylin Alexander, not Marilyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Old Vaccines May Stop the Coronavirus, Study Hints. Scientists Are Skeptical.
description: Certain vaccines may provide broad protection against infections. But new research doesn’t prove these vaccines can turn back the coronavirus, experts said.
content: Billions of dollars are being invested in the development of vaccines against the coronavirus. Until one arrives, many scientists have turned to tried-and-true vaccines to see whether they may confer broad protection, and may reduce the risk of coronavirus infection, as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Lampert
title: During the Pandemic, More Women Must Miscarry at Home
description: Some women who sought surgical treatment for miscarriage were turned away in the spring. Experts worry it could happen again.
content: Elena Castilla learned she was pregnant with twins in early February. Castilla, 32, lives in New Jersey but works as a teacher outside Philadelphia. She and her husband had been trying to conceive for years and were overjoyed to learn she was finally pregnant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe
title: Lawmakers, United in Their Ire, Lash Out at Big Tech’s Leaders
description: The chiefs of Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook faced withering questions from Democrats about anti-competitive practices and from Republicans about anti-conservative bias.
content: WASHINGTON — The chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook, four tech giants worth nearly $5 trillion combined, faced withering questions from Republican and Democratic lawmakers alike on Wednesday for the tactics and market dominance that had made their enterprises successful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Two Women Charged in Attack on Wisconsin State Senator
description: Tim Carpenter said he was punched and kicked after he recorded video of demonstrators at a protest in the capital, Madison, last month.
content: Two women were arrested and accused of beating a state senator who had been recording video of protesters last month, during a night of intensifying violence in Madison, Wis., the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Macdonald
title: The Mysterious Life of Birds Who Never Come Down
description: Swifts spend all their time in the sky. What can their journeys tell us about the future?
content: I found a dead common swift once, a husk of a bird under a bridge over the River Thames, where sunlight from the water cast bright scribbles on the arches above. I picked it up, held it in my palm, saw the dust in its feathers, its wings crossed like dull blades, its eyes tightly closed, and realized that I didn’t know what to do. This was a surprise. Encouraged by books, I’d always been the type of Gothic amateur naturalist who preserved interesting bits of the dead. I cleaned and polished fox skulls; disarticulated, dried and kept the wings of roadkill birds. But I knew, looking at the swift, that I could not do anything like that to it. The bird was suffused with a kind of seriousness very akin to holiness. I didn’t want to leave it there, so I took it home, swaddled it in a towel and tucked it in the freezer. It was in early May the next year, as soon as I saw the first returning swifts flowing down from the clouds, that I knew what I had to do. I went to the freezer, took out the swift and buried it in the garden one hand’s-width deep in earth newly warmed by the sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: N.B.A. Restart Preview: The Lakers and Clippers Stare Down the West
description: Anticipation built for a Western Conference finals played entirely in one arena. It’s still possible, but in Florida instead.
content: Almost exactly a year ago, on a sticky summer afternoon in Los Angeles, the Clippers staged a news conference for their two new headliners, Kawhi Leonard and Paul George. The duo sat on a platform inside a recreation center gymnasium that was packed with fans, reporters and team employees. For a long-suffering franchise, the event had the feel of a genuine celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: This Moss Uses Quartz as a Parasol
description: In the Mojave Desert, a translucent crystal offers bryophytes much-needed respite from the heat of the sun.
content: To humans, a desert oasis may conjure an image of a blue pool encircled by a coronet of palm trees. But to certain mosses, an oasis takes the form of a pebble of milky quartz. The cloudy crystal dilutes the sun’s piercing ultraviolet rays and, in the dry desert heat, traps moisture beneath it, creating a microclimate perfect for a moss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: N.B.A. Season Restart Preview: In the East, Where Do the Bucks Stop?
description: Milwaukee led the Eastern Conference before the season was suspended in March, but a few teams could pose challenges as Giannis Antetokounmpo tries to take the Bucks to the finals.
content: Hello, basketball, my old friend. I’ve come to talk to you again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Michael Phelps: ‘I Can’t See Any More Suicides’
description: In the documentary “The Weight of Gold,” Phelps presents a stark picture of the mental wear and tear Olympians endure.
content: The relationship between the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee and its most decorated Olympian, Michael Phelps, has been rocky for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Californians Support Black Lives Matter and Wearing Masks
description: Wednesday: A recent survey shows Californians are largely aligned, but differences of opinion reflect disparities. Also: L.G.B.T.Q. coronavirus data; and Emmy nominations.
content: Let’s begin with an update on the coronavirus crisis, which has hit the state particularly hard. California had two of the earliest deaths from Covid-19 in the United States. It has had more cases than any other state in the nation, and the pandemic is showing few signs of letting up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: High Schoolers Across the Country Are Seeking ‘Teenager Therapy’
description: A podcast started by five teens from a bedroom has become a lifeline for students.
content: As the pandemic has upended school, summer plans, and daily life for millions of teenagers, many are turning to a podcast to cope. “Teenager Therapy,” hosted by five rising seniors at Loara High School in Anaheim, Calif., has become a lifeline for kids and a breakout hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Help Me Find Trump’s ‘Anarchists’ in Portland
description: The president has his politically driven narrative. And then there’s reality.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — I’ve been on the front lines of the protests here, searching for the “radical-left anarchists” who President Trump says are on Portland streets each evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carina Chocano
title: ‘I May Destroy You’ Is Perfect TV for an Anxious World
description: The HBO drama about trauma is possibly the most emblematic show of 2020.
content: The sixth episode of HBO’s “I May Destroy You” opens on a bucolic urban scene: a park under a train overpass, where three young friends are attempting some plein-air spray-painting on canvas. Terry and Kwame have come to support Arabella, whose therapist has recommended painting to help her heal from a recent sexual assault. But Arabella doesn’t paint. She stands apart from her friends, engrossed in her phone. Terry, concerned, points this out to Kwame, but he shrugs: Arabella looks fine to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Belarus Says Russian Mercenaries Planned to Disrupt August Election
description: State media says 33 Russian fighters have been arrested in Belarus, dramatically escalating a feud between longtime allies.
content: MOSCOW — Escalating a simmering feud with Russia, its neighbor and longtime ally, Belarus on Wednesday charged that more than 200 mercenaries from Russia, disguised as tourists, had infiltrated Belarus on a mission to disrupt its presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset
title: Atlanta Mourns John Lewis and Ponders Carrying On With ‘Good Trouble’
description: The congressman and civil rights leader preached in support of nonviolent resistance, a message that some say must live on in his absence.
content: ATLANTA — A motorcade on Wednesday led John Lewis on one final tour of Atlanta, the city he represented in Congress for more than three decades and a place he helped establish as the spiritual home of a nonviolent movement to protest racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Griffin
title: Adding a New Name to the Canon in Clay: Doyle Lane
description: The underrecognized Black ceramist made tiny “weed pots” in the 1960s and ’70s that are seen today on a fresh pedestal.
content: LOS ANGELES — One afternoon in the early ’90s, the banking consultant Rudy Estrada returned to his mansion in Pasadena, Calif., to find two members of the local sheriff’s department standing over a lightly built African-American man spread-eagled on his front lawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Getting to Mars Is Easy. It’s the Stopping That Can Kill You.
description: The United States has an unparalleled record of success on the red planet’s surface, but NASA’s engineers aren’t resting on their laurels.
content: When NASA’s Perseverance rover arrives at Mars, mission managers will be watching, helpless to do anything. The $2.4 billion spacecraft will hit the top of the Martian atmosphere at more than 12,000 miles per hour and then come to a complete stop seven minutes later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Will the Penny Survive Coronavirus? Some Hope Not
description: Coins in circulation have become scarcer because fewer people are using them during the pandemic, renewing a debate over whether pennies have outlived their usefulness.
content: A nationwide coin shortage caused by the coronavirus pandemic has revived a debate: Is now the time to eliminate the penny?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Latin America Is Facing a ‘Decline of Democracy’ Under the Pandemic
description: The coronavirus is battering Latin American health systems and economies. It is also threatening the region’s fragile political freedoms.
content: CARACAS, Venezuela — Postponed elections. Sidelined courts. A persecuted opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed meeting could provide fresh clues on how policymakers see the economy.
description: Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday will conclude a two-day policy meeting that is likely to yield little action — rates are already at near-zero and are almost certain to stay there for an extended period — but could provide a fresh read on how policymakers are thinking about the economic outlook, and hints about their plans for the future.
content: Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday will conclude a two-day policy meeting that is likely to yield little action — rates are already at near-zero and are almost certain to stay there for an extended period — but could provide a fresh read on how policymakers are thinking about the economic outlook, and hints about their plans for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: When a Quarantine Comic-Con Keeps Fans at a Distance
description: Comic-Con International in San Diego recreated panels and viewing events for its online-only incarnation but left out ways for fans to interact. Our critic asks, what does that spell for the future of fandoms?
content: Every year, for several days in late July, the San Diego Convention Center is usually animated with people taking part in Comic-Con International. During the last few years, more than 130,000 convention attendees — lifelong fans, collectors, artists and culture vultures — swarmed the city for the event. It’s nerd heaven: exclusive panels and screenings from big studios like Disney and FX, interactive fan experiences like gaming centers and meet-ups, vendors with discounts and deals and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Ex-C.I.A. Chief Criticizes Silence of Top Republicans on Russian Interference
description: A new book by John Brennan is another salvo in the political debate over the intelligence community’s investigation of the election interference campaign.
content: WASHINGTON — In the final days of the Obama administration, intelligence officials laid out evidence of Russia’s 2016 election interference campaign to congressional leaders, prompting Nancy Pelosi, then the House minority leader, to press for Moscow to be punished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Are the Polls Missing Republican Voters?
description: Registered Republicans were actually more likely than registered Democrats to respond to the Times/Siena survey.
content: With polls showing Joe Biden holding a commanding lead, one question keeps popping up: Are these polls missing Trump voters?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: Coronavirus Deaths, Big Tech, Clay Food: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Hater’ Review: Resentments and Revenge via Digital Disinformation
description: In this Polish film from Jan Komasa, a villainous internet troll makes the personal political, and worse.
content: “The Hater,” a new Netflix movie directed by Jan Komasa from a script by Mateusz Pacewicz, does a lot of telegraphing before getting down to jackhammering. Tomasz (Maciej Musialowski), the title character, is first seen as a law student in Warsaw being called to account for plagiarizing a paper. Facing his professors, one of whom he obsequiously flatters, he smirks in a way that suggests he might soon break out into “Tomorrow Belongs to Me,” the Nazi anthem from “Cabaret.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Catch up: Universal-AMC deal, L Brands layoffs and more
description: Here are some of the big stories from Tuesday:
content: Here are some of the big stories from Tuesday:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pilon and Travon Free
title: This Great Black Baseball Player Still Isn’t in the Hall of Fame
description: John Donaldson died in obscurity, his statistics devalued because he played before baseball was integrated.
content: Most baseball fans have probably never heard of John Donaldson, a hard-throwing pitcher who drew sold-out crowds around the country for an astonishing three decades before he hung up his glove in 1941. His statistics establish him as one of the greatest to ever play America’s pastime. Yet he died in obscurity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: ‘Nobody Likes Me,’ Trump Complains, Renewing Defense of Dubious Science
description: The president lamented that his poll numbers were lower than those of his top science advisers. “It can only be my personality,” he said.
content: President Trump devolved into self-pity during a White House coronavirus briefing on Tuesday, lamenting that his approval ratings were lower than those of two top government medical experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Watermelon Salad Is Meant for Hot Days
description: You can use any kind of pickled chiles in this refreshing summery dish.
content: I’d never seen a watermelon small enough to fit in my purse until about a decade ago. But lately, they seem to be everywhere, which is a huge boon to my pandemic melon consumption. Because without a large group to help devour the 20-odd pounds of a standard watermelon, it feels a little sad to lug one home. And as practical as those plastic-wrapped wedges may be, they’re never quite as juicy or as satisfying as what you get from hacking into an intact melon yourself and plunging your biggest knife into its dripping, pink heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Bernie Sanders Is Asking for Masks for All
description: A national campaign to encourage mask wearing, including the distribution of free masks, would help to check the pandemic.
content: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont introduced legislation this week that directs the Trump administration to send three “high-quality, reusable” masks to every person in the United States, and would provide $5 billion to increase mask production. This is a good idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Yancy
title: Don’t Fear Dying. Fear Violence.
description: Why do millions of practitioners of the Jain religion strive to avoid harming even microscopic creatures?
content: This month’s conversation in our series exploring religion and death is with Pankaj Jain (@ProfPankajJain), an associate professor in the department of philosophy and religion at the University of North Texas. He is the author of “Dharma in America: A Short History of Hindu-Jain Diaspora,” “Dharma and Ecology of Hindu Communities: Sustenance and Sustainability” and other works. He is currently translating “Jain Darshan,” a text on the philosophy of Jainism. In 2019, he appeared in the TV series “The Story of God” with the actor Morgan Freeman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bobi Wine
title: My Torture at the Hands of America’s Favorite African Strongman
description: Yoweri Museveni, the country’s president and the Pentagon’s closest military ally in Africa, deploys security forces to assault opposition lawmakers.
content: KAMPALA, Uganda — Brutal policing is a global crisis, but America’s favorite African strongman, Yoweri Museveni, Uganda’s president since 1986, has deployed his own security forces to a particularly malign end: assaulting opposition parliamentary lawmakers to crush the democratic challenge he is facing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Anti-Mask Louie Gohmert Tests Positive, Sending Shudders Through Congress
description: The Texas congressman, who frequently refused to wear a mask, said he had probably contracted the coronavirus because he did so. His diagnosis raised questions about the spread of the virus on Capitol Hill.
content: Representative Louie Gohmert, a Texas Republican who has frequently refused to don a face covering in the Capitol, confirmed on Wednesday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus before a planned trip with President Trump on Air Force One, and he blamed his diagnosis on wearing a mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $3 Million Homes in California, Illinois and Maine
description: A midcentury-modern house in Brentwood, a 1910 home outside Chicago and a 28-acre seasonal camp on Mount Desert Island.
content: The exterior of this house is familiar to many as that of “The Golden Girls,” the NBC sitcom that ran from 1985 through 1992, about four women sharing a Miami ranch house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Bahrain Buys Into Paris F.C., With Plans to Use It as a Billboard
description: The kingdom’s investment has made it the latest Gulf country to try to improve its nation’s image by attaching it to a European soccer club.
content: For years, soccer in Paris has been the hub of Qatar’s global ambitions. Through its ownership of the city’s biggest team, Paris St.-Germain, Qatar has dreamed big, spent big and won big. In doing so, the country has also used the sport’s popularity to enhance its profile on the world stage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Plays On Racist Fears About Low-Income Housing
description: President Trump said he and Vladimir Putin did not discuss reported Russian bounties for killing American troops. A new poll shows Mr. Trump and Joe Biden locked in a tight race in Georgia.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Something That Is Bid
description: Amanda Chung and Karl Ni are really asking a lot of us.
content: Administrivial alert: The Games team continues to work on the issue with the downloadable PDFs. During the meanwhile, here is the Wednesday puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Judge Blocks Green Card Wealth Tests, Citing Pandemic Hardships
description: Deaths top 150,000 in the United States. A $600 unemployment benefit is likely to lapse on Friday, a top official said. In Iran, religious ceremonies and college-entrance exams are in limbo.
content: A federal judge on Wednesday blocked the Trump administration from moving forward with plans to deny green cards to immigrants who have received Medicaid, food stamps or housing vouchers, even on a limited basis — a wealth test that several states, led by New York, sued over during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: The Essential Tana French
description: If you want to brush up before her new novel arrives this fall, here’s your guide.
content: Tana French has written seven novels, with an eighth due in October. There are important things they have in common. They’re superb. They’re set in Ireland. They pull you way down rabbit holes. They play devious tricks with memory. And they’ll work as haunting diversions from the stasis of now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: Kerry James Marshall’s Black Birds Take Flight in a New Series
description: Inspired by John James Audubon, the painter explores the societal “pecking order” in two works that dovetail with “this mystery about whether or not Audubon himself was Black.”
content: About 10 years ago, the artist Kerry James Marshall caught a crow with his bare hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Racist Incident From Bronx Zoo’s Past Draws Apology
description: The Wildlife Conservation Society apologized for an incident from 1906 when a Central African man was placed on exhibit at the zoo, and for its association with two eugenicists.
content: The Wildlife Conservation Society, which operates the Bronx Zoo, three other zoos and an aquarium in New York, apologized Wednesday for two aspects of its history that the society’s chief executive described as demonstrating “unconscionable racial intolerance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Bray and Christy Hoffman
title: We Have a Question for Jeff Bezos and Other Billionaires
description: Will you finally let your workers unionize?
content: Covid-19 has created strange bedfellows. Six months ago we, a labor leader and an Amazon vice president, would have been on opposite sides in discussing the future of work at Big Tech in general and Amazon in particular. Then on May 1, one of us, Tim, walked away from a senior role at Amazon Web Services, and potentially millions in compensation, in protest over the firing of workers who spoke out about conditions in the company’s warehouses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Proud of the Kids
description: A mother recounts what her 12-year-old daughter and her friends are saying about returning to school and notes, “I was awed by them.” Also: The story behind the flour.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘It’s Been a Crazy Couple Days’: The Yankees’ Virus-Scrambled Week
description: The Yankees’ plans changed seemingly by the hour this week, part of the ripple effects of the Miami Marlins’ outbreak.
content: The Yankees’ equipment truck was leaving Philadelphia on Tuesday afternoon, and the team buses were scheduled to do the same in about 45 minutes. Their game against the Phillies had been postponed, just like the previous night’s game matchup, so they were headed back to New York to get ready for a Wednesday game in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Tingley
title: Why Is There No Consensus About Reopening Schools?
description: Here’s what we know: With too many variables and too few studies, schools lack the tools and data they need to balance education and health.
content: Is it possible to reopen school buildings in the fall in a way that keeps kids, educators, staff and their families and communities safe from Covid-19? Is it possible not to do so without harming them in other ways? Already, school closures have set children behind academically. More than 20 million children rely on school breakfasts and lunches. Too many parents face the choice between losing their jobs or leaving their children at home unsupervised. Vaccination rates for various dangerous diseases, typically required before students can attend school, have plummeted. Isolating children from their peers exacts social and emotional costs, which differ by age group and are nearly impossible to quantify. And whether schools reopen or remain closed, the risks are borne disproportionately by low-income communities and people of color. “This is really one of the most perplexing and complex issues I’ve ever faced in 40 years,” says Dan M. Cooper, a professor of pediatrics at the University of California, Irvine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: 8 Factors in the N.B.A.’s Return That May Upend Expectations
description: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein discusses a threat to the Lakers’ championship hopes, Lou Williams and the latest in his quest for the perfect cup of coffee.
content: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Titans of Tech Testify in Their Trust-Me Suits
description: It’s a tongue twister, but also a strategy. Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, Tim Cook and Sundar Pichai appeared before Congress and dressed the part.
content: They didn’t look like titans. They didn’t look like masters of the universe. They didn’t look like “emperors of the online economy,” as Representative David Cicilline, chairman of the antitrust subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee and Democrat from Rhode Island, called them. Nor did they look like “cyber barons,” as Representative Jamie Raskin, a Democrat from Maryland, said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Big Tech Hearings, Vietnam Outbreak, Sheep Shortage: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Anderson
title: China’s Arms Buildup Threatens the Nuclear Balance
description: A Pentagon leader argues that as Beijing’s weapons grow in size and sophistication, the U.S. and Russia will have to reassess their own arsenals.
content: Nuclear arms control is at a crossroads — not because we are approaching the deadline on an extension of the 2010 New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, but because China’s nuclear expansion threatens to upend decades of relative nuclear stability between the United States and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: 9 Great Movies to Stream on Peacock
description: Dive into the new NBCUniversal streaming service to discover these excellent (and free) options.
content: Peacock has taken wing, and NBCUniversal’s streaming service distinguishes itself from fellow newcomers Disney+ and HBO Max by offering 15,000 hours of film and TV for free, if viewers are willing to tolerate ad breaks. With enough entertainment to stretch to March 2022 without sleeping, where to begin? The Universal monsters, like the Mummy and the Wolf Man, are an obvious start. Other self-celebratory categories on the home page include movies starring “S.N.L.” alums and a salute to Alfred Hitchcock, who was loyal to the studio for 43 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Chau Doan
title: Mysterious Coronavirus Outbreak Catches Vietnam by Surprise
description: After months without a single coronavirus death, or even a confirmed case of local transmission, a new outbreak has struck Vietnam. And it’s spreading.
content: In a world plagued by pandemic, Vietnam seemed like a miracle. As months went by without a single recorded coronavirus death, or even a confirmed case of local transmission, residents began leaving their face masks at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Madeleine Albright on Covid-19, Fascism and Her Dream Superhero Team
description: “We are in one of the most crucial periods that I’ve ever seen,” the former secretary of state said.
content: — Secretary Madeleine Albright
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Hamilton
title: Bored With Your Home Cooking? Some Smoky Eggplant Will Fix That
description: These crispy-silky croquettes rise to the restaurant level of cooking we’ve been missing.
content: Lately I’ve been worn out by my own home cooking. It’s not the toil that’s getting to me; it’s more that I feel fatigued by the familiarity of it: the predictability of my own kitchen habits, the recognizability of my own cooking voice, the monotony of what I always throw in my cart as I zigzag the aisles at the grocery store on autopilot. Everyone I know has had a similar malaise recently — all of us feeling rather short on enthusiasm for this monogamous intimacy with our three-ingredient tendencies and our everything-shoved-on-a-sheet-pan ways, no matter how beloved and delicious the results have reliably been. And so I’ve begun reaching for new ideas, new paths, new routes to new pleasures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: A Wrinkle in Stores’ Mask Policies: Enforcement
description: A number of large retailers have said that all customers must wear masks, but some employees have been told they cannot force those who refuse.
content: Christopher Vanderpool works shifts as a “health ambassador” at a Walmart in Fayetteville, N.C., For $11 an hour, he stands in the parking lot asking customers to put on masks before entering the store.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch live: Fed Chair speaks about the state of the U.S. economic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: The Director Gina Prince-Bythewood Has Always Had Game
description: Our readers and critic revisited “Love & Basketball,” the director’s feature debut about a Black girl who plays ball, falls in love and carves out her own path to happiness.
content: There are different reasons I adore “Love & Basketball”: its tenacious athlete-heroine, its twinned belief in female tears and female ambition, Alfre Woodard’s artful supporting turn. The film won me over when I first saw it in 2000. But it wasn’t until I looked at it again for our Weekend Watch that I realized that the director Gina Prince-Bythewood had given herself a sly cameo. She plays one of our heroine’s opponents, who dives to the floor alongside her midgame as they scramble for the ball. It’s such a perfect encapsulation of the movie and its themes that I watched it again and again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas, Daisuke Wakabayashi, Karen Weise and Mike Isaac
title: A Handbook to Today’s Tech Hearing
description: The C.E.O.s are likely to argue before Congress that their companies aren’t anticompetitive. Here are the facts.
content: Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Tim Cook of Apple, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and Sundar Pichai of Google are set to testify before Congress on Wednesday to make their case about why their companies actually are not that powerful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: North Bergen, N.J.: Reasonably Priced and Minutes From Manhattan
description: Supporters praise the community’s young, culturally diverse population and its (relatively) affordable housing. And then there are the views.
content: In 1975, Calvin Trillin wrote in The New Yorker magazine about “the half-dozen cities in northern Hudson County that are, except for some arbitrary and invisible lines drawn every mile or so, one mass of blue-collar sprawl running along the Hudson, just across from midtown Manhattan.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Commerce Department Asks F.C.C. to Narrow Protections for Web Platforms
description: The request comes as President Trump continues to accuse tech platforms like Facebook and Twitter of suppressing conservative content.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration asked the Federal Communications Commission this week to narrow its interpretation of a law that shields internet platforms like Facebook and YouTube from certain lawsuits over the content they host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Randle
title: Renada McGuire, Resilient Home Health Aide, Dies at 39
description: She decided to work with adults with mental disabilities after giving birth to a child with challenges. She died of complications of the novel coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Joseph Kernan, Vietnam P.O.W. and Indiana Governor, Dies at 74
description: He spent 11 months in a North Vietnamese prison after his plane was downed. He was later a long-serving mayor of South Bend.
content: Joseph Kernan, a naval aviator who served nearly a year as a prisoner of war after he was shot down over North Vietnam in 1972, then returned to Indiana to become a popular mayor, lieutenant governor and governor, died on Wednesday in South Bend, Ind. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Federal Reserve Leaves Rates Near Zero as Economic Recovery Sputters
description: Federal Reserve officials made clear that they will work to bolster the economy as the pandemic hurts business activity and the job market.
content: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve left interest rates near zero on Wednesday and Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, predicted a long road ahead as a recent spike in virus cases saps momentum from the nascent economic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt
title: Trump Says He Did Not Ask Putin About Suspected Bounties to Kill U.S. Troops
description: Amid no new signs of investigative developments, the president also said for the first time that he would have acted had he known about an earlier C.I.A. assessment.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump said in an interview published Wednesday that he did not bring up intelligence that Russia had covertly offered bounties to kill American troops when he spoke with President Vladimir V. Putin last week — apparently his first opportunity to directly confront Mr. Putin about the C.I.A. assessment since its existence became public late last month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Confronting China
description: Some members of the Trump administration believe the superpower country poses an existential threat to the U.S. — one they are working to address now.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: The Horror of Isolation
description: Three new movies show why this cinematic genre is best suited to the Covid-19 era, when isolation has become not just a way of life, but necessary to avoid deaths.
content: The first essential of a good horror film is an isolated place. Any desolate locale will do: cabin in the woods, empty motel, middle of the ocean, Detroit, just somewhere no one can hear you scream. Populate it with potential victims, add a monster and you’ve got everything you need to make things go bump in the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Families Across the U.S. Struggle to Afford Diapers, Wipes and Formula
description: Over 56 million families have lost income since March 13, and diaper banks are straining to fill the need.
content: A few months ago, Chelsea Murgatroyd turned to her local diaper bank for a supply of diapers and wipes. Murgatroyd, 29, who has a 4-year-old and 8-month-old in Austin, Texas, co-owned a carpet cleaning business with her husband that opened two years ago. They worked mostly with hotels, but as soon as the coronavirus shutdown happened in March, “all our work was gone,” she said, and ultimately they had to shutter the business. Their savings went quickly. Murgatroyd found the Austin Diaper Bank through a Google search. “We needed help,” she said. “I have never used a charity in my life. That was very different and humbling for me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: MacKenzie Scott Gives $1.7 Billion to Historically Black Colleges and Other Groups
description: One year after pledging to give away most of her fortune, Ms. Scott, an author and the ex-wife of Jeff Bezos, announced that she had donated to causes supporting women, L.G.B.T. rights and racial equality.
content: MacKenzie Scott, one of the world’s richest women, pledged one year ago to give away her money “until the safe is empty.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Is Your Blood Sugar Undermining Your Workouts?
description: Eating a diet high in sugar and processed foods could dent our long-term health in part by changing how well our bodies respond to exercise.
content: People with consistently high levels of blood sugar could get less benefit from exercise than those whose blood sugar levels are normal, according to a cautionary new study of nutrition, blood sugar and exercise. The study, which involved rodents and people, suggests that eating a diet high in sugar and processed foods, which may set the stage for poor blood sugar control, could dent our long-term health in part by changing how well our bodies respond to a workout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Retailers have strong rules on masks, but weak enforcement.
description: Big retailers have made strong statements recently about their new rules requiring customers to wear face masks when shopping, saying that the health of their workers and customers is paramount.
content: Big retailers have made strong statements recently about their new rules requiring customers to wear face masks when shopping, saying that the health of their workers and customers is paramount.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Hong Kong’s economy shrank by 9 percent in the second quarter.
description: The fallout of the global coronavirus pandemic has pulled Hong Kong’s economy further into decline over the past three months, with the Chinese territory on Wednesday reporting a 9 percent contraction.
content: The fallout of the global coronavirus pandemic has pulled Hong Kong’s economy further into decline over the past three months, with the Chinese territory on Wednesday reporting a 9 percent contraction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: ‘Shine Your Eyes’ Review: Reimagining São Paulo
description: This feature from the Brazilian filmmaker Matias Mariani, finds a distinctive way to tell a familiar immigrant narrative.
content: A man comes to São Paulo to find his brother. What he discovers, however, is a city more alluring than he could have imagined. “Shine Your Eyes,” from the Brazilian filmmaker Matias Mariani, finds a distinctive way to tell a familiar narrative — of immigrants in megacities, of how dreams can pummel you and of the complexity of fraternal bonds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Danielle Ivory, Mitch Smith, Alex Lemonides and Lauryn Higgins
title: More Than 6,300 Coronavirus Cases Have Been Linked to U.S. Colleges
description: A Times survey of hundreds of schools represents the most comprehensive look at the toll the virus has already taken on the country’s colleges and universities.
content: A Times survey of hundreds of schools represents the most comprehensive look at the toll the virus has already taken on the country’s colleges and universities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $3 Million
description: A midcentury-modern house in Los Angeles, a 1910 home outside Chicago and a 28-acre seasonal camp on Mount Desert Island in Maine.
content: A midcentury-modern house in Los Angeles, a 1910 home outside Chicago and a 28-acre seasonal camp on Mount Desert Island in Maine.

title: Cape Cod Style on the Shores of Nova Scotia
description: This five-bedroom seaside mansion, perched on a headland jutting into Mahone Bay in Nova Scotia, Canada, is on the market for $2 million.
content: This five-bedroom seaside mansion, perched on a headland jutting into Mahone Bay in Nova Scotia, Canada, is on the market for $2 million.

description: Supporters praise the community’s young, culturally diverse population and its (relatively) affordable housing. And then there are the views.

author: By Twitter
title: Video Shows ‘Umbrella Man’ Smashing Windows in Minneapolis
description: The police in Minneapolis said they have linked a man dressed in black, wearing a gas mask and holding an umbrella, to a white supremacy group, and accused him of trying to provoke violence.
content: The police in Minneapolis said they have linked a man dressed in black, wearing a gas mask and holding an umbrella, to a white supremacy group, and accused him of trying to provoke violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Video Shows Burning Freight Train on Arizona Bridge
description: A freight train derailed and caught fire as it crossed a bridge in Tempe, Ariz., causing it to partially collapse.
content: A freight train derailed and caught fire as it crossed a bridge in Tempe, Ariz., causing it to partially collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Economy’s Path Forward Is ‘Extraordinarily Uncertain,’ Powell Says
description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell said a full recovery was unlikely until Americans felt safe to “re-engage in a broad range of activities.”
content: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell said a full recovery was unlikely until Americans felt safe to “re-engage in a broad range of activities.”
